trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of a very short Wi-Fi pulse on brain activity in healthy volunteers: fMRI double blind randomized study.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of a single, REAC pulse on brain activity in healthy volunteers: fMRI double blind randomized pilot study.

conditions.healthcondition: Studies of the normal brain and nervous system

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of the normal brain and nervous system

interventions.interventions: Study to examine with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) the effects on brain activity of voluntary healthy subjects, following a single, very low power 250 ms transcutaneous radio electric asymmetric conveyer pulse applied via electrode placed on the ear pavillion for 500 ms.
interventions.comparator: Placebo. Placebo treatment, is the same device was applied to those in treated group, but with the REAC field turned off. Placebo pulse applied via electrode placed on the ear pavillion for 500 ms.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Assess if the REAC pulse, well below the temporal resolution of fMRI, might show some effect on the brain. This outcome is assessed with fMRI examination.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: After administering either the REAC pulse or the placebo treatment, all subjects were brought back to the magnet room to repeat an fMRI examination.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Assess if the REAC pulse, well below the temporal resolution of fMRI, might show some effect on cerebellum activity. This outcome is assessed with fMRI examination.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: After administering either the REAC pulse or the placebo treatment, all subjects were brought back to the magnet room to repeat an fMRI examination.

trial_design.concealment: The person who determined if a subject was eligible for inclusion in the trial was unaware, when this decision was made, to which group the subject would be allocated.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Istituto di Radiologia, Universita degli Studi di Cagliari

fundingsource.fundingname: Istituto di Radiologia, Universita degli Studi di Cagliari
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Universita Degli Studi di Cagliari Policlinico Universitario Strada Statale 554, KM. 4.500 postcode: 09042 Monserrato (CA)

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Istituto Rinaldi Fontani Viale Belfiore 43 50144 Firenze

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Background: Electromagnetic brain stimulation techniques have been used to map brain areas, to treat psychiatric disorders such as depression and rehabilitation. Often to see the changes of activation or inhibition of brain areas or to assess any change in synaptic plasticity induced by these stimuli, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is used. Methods This double blind randomized pilot study, is the first study to examine with functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) the effects on brain activity of voluntary healthy subjects, following a single, very low power 250 ms transcutaneous radio electric asymmetric conveyer (REAC) pulse. The primary target of this study was to assess if the REAC pulse, well below the temporal resolution of fMRI, might show some effect on the brain and particularly on cerebellum activity.
